title: Cheriyal Scroll Painting
summary: Cheriyal scroll painting is a traditional stylized religious cloth-scroll art originating from Telangana, India. These narrative paintings, resembling film rolls or comic strips, depict stories from Indian mythology, Puranas, and Epics. Historically, they were prevalent across Andhra and other regions, used as 'Charanachitras' or 'Yamapatas' for didactic storytelling, educating the unlettered with visual aids and recitations. The earliest known reference dates back to the 2nd century BC in Mahabhashya. Once widespread, the art form has seen a significant decline with the advent of television, cinemas, and computers, and is now primarily made only in Hyderabad, specifically in Cheriyal town. It shares common origins with other textile scroll paintings like Patachitra and Phad.
key_points: Cheriyal scroll painting is a stylized religious cloth-scroll art from Telangana, India.
It features a narrative format, depicting stories from Indian mythology, Puranas, and Epics.
Historically, these scrolls served as didactic tools, educating the unlettered through visual storytelling and as devotional souvenirs for pilgrims.
The art form has declined significantly due to modern media and is now primarily confined to Hyderabad, specifically Cheriyal town.
It shares common origins with other traditional textile scroll paintings like Patachitra and Phad.
